abstract.p: Eric Beck letter holds J Hoberman's July 30 article ignores signs that blue-collar workers, not just hippies, were rebelling in 1960's (S)

block.p: The traditional narrative of the 60's, which J. Hoberman faithfully adheres to in his article, assumes that the revolt by the hippies and students was opposed by a moribund middle class and an increasingly conservative, hippie-hating working class. It's a neat little story, but like many such narratives, the evidence supporting it is slight, when it's not contradictory.

The traditional narrative of the 60's, which J. Hoberman faithfully adheres to in his article, assumes that the revolt by the hippies and students was opposed by a moribund middle class and an increasingly conservative, hippie-hating working class. It's a neat little story, but like many such narratives, the evidence supporting it is slight, when it's not contradictory.

Yes, there were Joes in the working class. But Mr. Hoberman ignores the signs that blue-collar workers were also in rebellion. In the years 1968-1973 there was a record number of both official and wildcat strikes, the intensity of which hadn't been seen since the 30's. Also, many blue-collar workers were rebelling in ways similar to the middle-class kids: smoking pot, growing their hair long, trying to undermine their bosses.
